metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Premises consist of an open piece of land adjoining Haines Road in Bombay.
Prior to 1963, land belonged to Sir Shapurji Bharucha Mills Co. Ltd.
In 1953, land purchased by Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd.
In 1947, land leased to Allenbury Co. on monthly rent of Rs. 1800/- where lessee kept American vehicles used by army during WWII purchased from Disposal Department.
In or about 1950, appellant-company incorporated to take over business of Allenbury Co. including assets and vehicles.
In 1954, appellant-company occupied leased land as tenant at Rs. 1800/- per month with remaining undisposed vehicles.
Document of lease executed providing for 10-year lease according to appellant, but unregistered and could not be tendered in evidence.
Appellant paid and respondents accepted rent of Rs. 1800/- per month throughout.
On January 20, 1960, Bharat Insurance served notice terminating tenancy on ground of sub-letting, demanding vacant possession.
Appellant failed to vacate, suit filed in Court of Small Causes, Bombay; plaintiff substituted by Life Insurance Corporation after nationalisation.
Suit and appeal in Small Causes proceeded on basis of landlord-tenant relationship, irrespective of terms as document unregistered.
Special Civil Application under Art. 227 in Bombay High Court against Small Causes judgments; High Court judgment dated June 16, 1971.
All courts held tenancy not proved for manufacturing purposes; notice valid despite being one month's notice.
Evidence: Premises had open land, sheds, godown; army vehicles stored; workshop for repairing/reconditioning vehicles.
Vehicles damaged: chassis missing/bent/broken; repaired, reconditioned, painted before sale; some new bodies/parts made.
189 vehicles in 1950-51; operations till 1957; workshop with lathes, drills, welders; 200-250 workmen.
Letter dated November 21, 1950 lists 182 vehicles, stores, spare parts, tools.
Witnesses (Choradia, Kannan) saw no manufacturing; only storage and minor repairs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the tenancy was for manufacturing purposes, requiring six months' notice under s. 106 TPA.
Impact of s. 107 TPA (requiring registration for leases over one year) on presumption under s. 106 TPA.

petitioner_arguments.text: Relationship of landlord and tenant admitted; rent accepted at Rs. 1800/- monthly; if tenancy for manufacturing purposes, presumption under s. 106 applies making it year-to-year terminable by six months' notice.
Lease was for manufacturing purposes; notice invalid even if one month.

respondent_arguments.text: Disputes construction of ss. 106 and 107 TPA suggested by petitioner.
Tenancy not proved for manufacturing purposes; dominant purpose storage and resale.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on appellant to prove tenancy for manufacturing purposes; must be exclusive or dominant purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Manufacturing implies transformation into new article with distinctive name, character or use.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence meager; even accepting appellant's evidence, dominant purpose storage and resale of vehicles; manufacturing of parts incidental.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant failed to establish dominant purpose as manufacturing.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide impact of s. 107 on s. 106 as manufacturing purpose not proved.

holdings.text: Tenancy not for manufacturing purposes; one month's notice valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Mockertich v. Steuart & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden to prove dominant purpose of lease is manufacturing.

precedents_cited.case_name: South Bihar Sugar Mills v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Manufacture requires transformation into new article.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Delhi Cloth General Mills
precedents_cited.relevance: Manufacture requires new and different article.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sedgwick v. Watley Combe, Reid and Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Not on meaning of manufacture but industrial hereditaments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Action Borough Council v. West Middlesex Assessment Committee

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption of tenancy from year to year for manufacturing purposes terminable by six months' notice; registration required for leases over one year.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special Civil Application filed in High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed upholding High Court; tenancy not for manufacturing purposes; notice valid. Appellant requested time to vacate premises.

key_quotes.text: "The burden of proving that the lease was for manufacturing purposes, must... lie on the party who claims it to be so... That burden is to establish that the exclusive or at least the dominant purpose of the lease was the manufacturing purpose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines burden of proof for s. 106 TPA.

key_quotes.text: "Manufacturing of spare parts would then be, merely incidental to the main purpose of disposal of these vehicles."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There must be such a transformation that a new and different article must emerge having a distinctive name, character or use."
key_quotes.speaker: court
